acRUL11lYFJLTgy6ehvMyQ.text: The ticket prices obviously depend on the how but the venue itself is great, the seats are comfortable but the audio can get a bit distorted when they pump the volume up. The staff are friendly too, could do with a bit of a clean up in some places though

7okWEK-GfUrD1EJCY3XGmA.text: The 02 arena was previoulsy called the dome (that having been one huge farce!) now owned by an american company called AEG they have transformed the old dome into something which was previously thought impossible- one of the worlds leading multi entertainment venue. the best way of seeing this is by foot- check out you're local travel for info. as you walk through the main doors you are hit with a sudden moment of awe, as the canopy is revealed. straight ahead is the main arena, where the likes of madonna have aready played to about 20'000 people. as you turn right into the restaraunt side of things, you will notice one thing- america rules the place. so far, plenty to eat, lol. keep going fruther and you will soon come to a space- to the right is the bubble (events vary) and to the left, top is the vue, a state of the art cinema) on the bottom is a club called inc- at 25 pounds a head just to get in, you'd better be ready to go bankrupt!. a little further up, just to the right, is indigo- a purpose night club that can be transformed into a live entertainment room in a flash. further on to the left is alcove that is used for exhibitions etc. finally, just to the end, on the right is londons newest (i don't know about biggest as it looks kind small) is matter- one of the most up to date clubs ever built- this opened in september 08, and has a fully hydraulic (movable) floor that can be adjusted to suit the individual band, although it is mainly a club, it does house music etc. if you need more info you can email me, or even better, check out the 02 site!

MSJtchd5Mqw_vTcMM8ChoQ.text: The O2 arena - who said it would never work? The millenium dome has been transformed from a disaster to an entertainment hub. There are lots of restaurants many of which are clearly Amercian chains that I've never heard of but was exicted by. View them as you walk down the red brick road and then when you finish you can munch a burger while you look out over the corpses of the bodyworks exhibition. Visit the wonderfully spacious Vue cinema with the best arms rests a cinema chair has ever seen. Finish by relaxing in the O2 chill out zone.

OXvMwFWQ4BKLJFomyGXqAg.text: An amazing venue if used to its full potential, really good acoustics, it looks great too, very modern, funky and new. The doorstaff are proffesional, helpful and in some cases excessivly friendly! It makes getting to your seat a smooth and stress-free experience. The bars and food counters are large and numerous, its still the usual concert burgers and beers though, think it would really add to the experience to be able to buy drinks that arent available at all Wetherspoons. The Stadium is huge which can be a good or bad thing, if you are standing and can get sort of middle to front then the view is great! However if you get seats somewhere at the top near the back then you can't see anything cause you are simply too far away, video screens are usually a good solution for this but they seem somewhat of a rarity at the gigs I've seen here, not sure if it the bands fault or the stadiums fault, but they need to get them now!

twfXdY3Vuc8chpLoK1HmHA.text: I went to see Bryan Adams at the O2. It is a great place for concerts, loads of restaurants, even Starbucks. The tube station is just outside the arena which is great.

HIvekC89eSTYhi9KUzLowA.text: I went to the O2 to see Beyonce and had the best night ever. Obviously she is amazing but we were lucky enough to have a box and the staff are so friendly and helpful. We were seated at the back of the arena and although the sound wasn't great with the supporting act, it was a spectacular show when beyonce performed. The O2 has so many bars and restaurants, it is easy to spend an evening there even if you aren't seeing a band.

P6LYM8SOrUCtYJ2q0zM6Zw.text: I went to see Beyonce at the O2 arena and it was amazing!! The diva herseft put on the most incredible show however the venue also was really great. What an awesome turnaround from the Millenium Dome. The most amazing atmosphere, easy to get to, loads of restaurants and bars so you can really make a night of it! Love, love, love!! One week later I bought my boyfriends sister for her 21st and mum tickets to see Beyonce too at the 02 because I was so impressed - there seats were quite high up but they said it was great, the view was still really good and the atmosphere was great too. In fact they were speechless for 10mins when they came out!

1DR8da0S9um2wvXleTNsYg.text: Where do I start with the O2 well best to say I just love it I suppose. I have now been there more times than I can remember for concerts, festivals and free days out. First off the auditorium for the shows is out of this world, it's so large but it's easy to see the stars on stage even from the back. The accoustics are great and the staff are very helpful and friendly. There is plenty of disabled areas and a carer gets in free for all concerts and shows and sometimes the disabled area is right next to the stage. There is tons and tons of parking with lots of disabled parking close to the entrances. The fees for parking can be a little steep but they are always half price with a blue badge. Now onto what else there is at the O2 apart from just the arena itself. There is the Indigo room which holds private small functions for around 250 people, they have things like Dylan Moran, Madness etc it's all very up close and personal and adults only. There are many many eateries in the O2 however be warned they are all very expensive and there's not a lot of choice for vegetarians. There is a state of the art cinema inside the O2 which is very grandiose and seats thousands, I think they have around 11 screens. My only real bug bear with the O2 and the reason I haven't given it 5 stars is the fact it's so dam cold all the time, there's no heating at all except in the eateries so if you're going along there make sure you dress warm. Thumbs up.

Y4jV_ilnd5uTCjAKRJwMvQ.text: great venue and the Tutankhamun exhibition is a must see, great bars and resturants and nice place to just hang out and relax.

RTyreaZLK9s1mVsHTmqE3g.text: great place for entertainment, is huge , has resaturants and bars, there is constantly a concert or a show there, they have even a cinema there, you can get there by bus, tube, even on the water by CATAMARAN, isnt this great , take a catamaran and set your foot on the Island the O2 is set on. awesome place to entertain

-TLVk0aJ-Rla5KBcRJ0dPQ.text: Finally they have done something usefull with the dome! Good venue for entertainment plenty of bars and restaurants and safe to get to and from late in the evening. The cinema and lots of events taking place there is just and added bonus. Gets quite crowded at he weekends.

qGQz2NGHz3AACWaJA-CfMA.text: great place to go specially with your partner nice romantic view and mouth watering food at different restaurants.. YUP, there are many places to try out food from so it VERY hard to choose which one you want to eat it.. Vue cinema is also located as well as the o2 Arena for the concerts,,so don't forget to check if any concerts are going on before you go thereso you can spend extra time there ;)

WLsd8IqolzY7FsvfPzED0g.text: I've never visited the O2 arena for a concert, so can't really comment on that, but we did go to both the cinema and the Tutankhamun exhibition. It is amazing to walk around 'the dome' because of it's scale and size, every corner you turn there seems to be something new. Plenty of restaurants to choose from, the food isn't cheap but where is in London? We especially liked the cinema as it's a VUE (my preferred chain because of the comfy seats) and it was handy being able to purchase the tickets on the ground floor before taking the escalator up to the cinema itself.

mW6GP5Kv-Ewpb2H-gDpKUQ.text: Like a whole other world! Really vast inside and worth a visit especially if your seeing a show. Didnt think much of the food choice when I went but then again I didnt have long till my show started and needed something fairly quick. had to settle for a salad in starbucks in the end!

iHoJ4JAiV1UBOTgqkO8Udg.text: went on 6th october 2010 to see supertramp travelled from london euston on the tube northern line to london bridge then jubilee line to north greenwich takes you right to the door of the o2 is a spectacular sight on the outside on the inside it is just a souless big shell unless you are in floor section A or lower tier either side of the stage your not going to see much as this venue is huge seating anywhere else the view was described to me as "ants on stage" and thats accurate the screens only seem to be on for 25% of the concert i was in floor section B row c but still was far from the stage once inside the dome your only choice of lager is becks at approx £4.50 a glass and the floor level bar closes once the concert starts giving you a climb to level 1 for another drink and long Q bacardi and coke same price but tasteless great to hear rick davies blasting out the supertramp hits but the poor efforts to recreate the rodger hodgson voice in his absence made supertramp more like a tribute/karaoke band with several vocalists struggling to match his voice and style of singing.better staying in your seat after the concert to aviod the cattle rush through the one remaining open exitwould recommend the pilot inn for pre drinks and meals a left turn out the main entrance of northgeenwich tube station a ten minute walk along millenium way on your left hand side choice of fresh fish salmon or sea bass at £9 and fosters £3 odd to avoid the o2 rip off

Go0YLhCD9mJIEP7Q-CWPlA.text: Drivers be warned, No road signs!!! Simple enough to get to Greenwich High St, but there are no signs to Mellenium Way. Book car park before you go( very expensive) and get there early as que to car park is rediculous. (Best to park couple of tube stations away and go by tube), There is a food and beverage mobile cabin outside the venue which is decent & has cheapest food and drink. Inside, an oasis drink is £3.00 double the cabin price and the food portions are tiny and triple high street price so if your starving eat at the cabin its cheaper. Note if you bring a bottle of drink when you go in security will take your lid (probably coz we were going to a concert). Also as you walk in the main entrance of the 02 there is an American style restaurant (one of many) on the immediate left (cant remember the name) dont bother, poor service, they got the order completely wrong and it was COLD (others were complaining too) and not worth the price. So be warned. There are many bars and reasturants as you go in to the alley on the right hand side. But all are very expensive. The arena itself is smaller than what i expected. The chairs are basic and space for leg room is tiny. So if you arent 'petite standard' under 5'3 (making reference to shop clothes size), expect to sit sideways or legs wide open, very unconfortable.Bring a long sleeve top as the the air con can get pretty cold. Staff are friendly and crowd control was good.

AA0jcEbRpwSw_zF2nkEo1Q.text: this is an awesome venue!the o2 has fabulous transport links, as one might expect. buses, taxis, undergrounds and plenty of parking - although that can be pricey when there is a concert on.inside, there are loads of bars and restaurants and a cinema. its a great place to go for a night out regardless of weather you are seeing a show!if you are seeing a show, prepare to be awestruck by its sheer size. i have been to a few shows, for one i sat at the side and to be honest was a bit frightened by the sheer drop in front of me. there is no safety bar (only at the front on blocks) and all that is stoppong you from tumbling is the seat in front (which came to about my knee) and your own balance. took me a while to get up and boogie!if you do want to go for sometihng to eat before the show, go early. queues can be gorrendously long - which you expect with some 10,000+ people crammed into the venue!if you are on o2 mobile contract, you can text them in advance and gain special entry to a vip (bar) area. i am not, but i have friends that are and its a lot quieter and more plush than the other bars.a great place - go see something!

E-_Vrdkx98XIJm16h44C4A.text: much more than just a music venue.Nightclubs, restaurant, and an all round quality night.Saw Basement Jaxx here in December.AWESOME!

BidrmAOryo8gfP1fdmoJ1w.text: This has got to be one of the MOST EXPENSIVE parking arenas in the WORLD!  The site cons people into paying £25 to park their car during a concert! yes £25 whereas when you drive in if you say you are going to the cinema and buy a ticket and then go to a concert you only end up paying under £10 for parking!!! So cinema ticket and parking ticket = £12-15 or be robbed by saying i  am going to the concert they divert you to a parking area 10 minutes away from the entrance and you pay £25! for the privilege... YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED.... VERY POOR & VERY EXPENSIVE

Fj6ywuTEvG22DTonFhdcOw.text: BAD ASS!! The design, while unique is truly original and awesome...however, 25 yrs from now I might have a different opinion.  I was there for a private event so I can't objectively comment on the concert space.  It seemed like all of the seats were good, but can't say.

JuBm3UHnPjGbC2BMI8ivww.text: The O2 is a real story of a phoenix rising from the ashes. I can't really comment first hand about this venue when it was born originally as the Millennium Dome. Fairly or unfairly, it got a bad press and its reputation never really recovered though I had friends who did make multiple visits there.The site stayed in limbo after the millennium until it was gloriously transformed into the O2 Arena. It is now probably the leading music venue in the country.I made my first visit here only recently for the Strictly Come Dancing roadshow and was mightily impressed. It is an enormous structure but has an impressive Tube station to cope with the crowds. There were a lot of stewards too to help marshall people into sensible streams of flow, which really helped.The main  auditorium was huge and we were lucky to have good seats. The higher seats are quite far away and apparently very steeply banked according to friends who have sat up there. However, the seats are a good size and I was quite comfortable for the 3 hour show.The acoustics were great and this is attracting many artists to shift allegiances from other venues.Besides the main performance area, there is a big cinema and multiple exhibitions going on. It's a complete entertainment venue. At peak times, the main walkways can get busy as people browse the restaurants but there is a good range of food options from Brazilian BBQs to Chinese buffets.Sadly, although venues like Wembley Arena have nostalgia and history, the O2 Arena is the future. One last tip is that O2 customers get priority on bookings for events held here.

rvAgx_ijhjM8_HsRBqMpfw.text: Now I knew this place was meant to be big but WOW.. I love this venue. The layout, the acoustics of the place and the feel of everything in general both in and around the place.  I am not sure if you dine at any of the restaurants in the vicinity what the quick service for food turn around is like but the bar I was in was great. Friendly and speedy service. The venue staff I felt were very thorough in getting people into the venue quickly, even with security checks (and having worked in event management in the past I have seen some unorganised venues that should be up to speed in this area). I hope to go to many a gig here in the future.

y4tjxr-NYuFDodUEO8g0fw.text: The O2 is like a small town in itself. There are so many different things to see and places to eat inside without ever having to enter the arena. If you are going to a show be sure to eat at one of the restaurants outside the concert area. The food inside is quite overpriced. As a concert venue, the screens and stage are perfect. Even though I was in the nose bleed section I really enjoyed my concert and had an amazing time.

LmqI-Y-y4_n9e5XG8Wliiw.text: Really enjoyed this venue-saw Roger Daltrey play Tommy and loved the show and the venue. The stage is surrounded by seating on a first come first served basis and has a bar open throughout the show.There is a cosy style to this venue-will definately go again

pOrY94E1D2KcFJsvPmal5Q.text: Maybe its because I've had the luxury of sitting in an executive box and taking in all the free food and beer that entails, but I like the o2 as a venue - a classic example of converting a white elephant into something useful. I have sat in the cheap seats as well - to see Prince - and that was good too - although the acoustics seemed to be better in the box as well. Food outlets do generally seem a bit overpriced and underwhelming but that's no different to any other arena you could mention. so yeah i like it.

fucdqOQ-T-KNdtDewAQ2SQ.text: I never visited O2 when it was then the Dome as it quickly became another of our countries/governments white elephants, but since O2 made their stamp on it I have visited here on many occasions, all for concerts. And like all stadia once in you are a captive audience everything becomes expensive, but the good thing about The O2 is that it's east to access from most geo points around and inside London, which opens up your choices for some reasonably priced food outside the zone. But that said if you are look on your visit as an experience then it shouldn't really phase you.

zA-3rtFBxLBlEA5Ixm7MVw.text: I think it was a universal notion shared by many astounded Londoners that a significant amount of money and good space was wasted on account of The Millennium Dome. Created in 2000, it was initially used as hub for 'The Millennium Experience'; an exhibition divided into 14 zones, illustrating multiple sectors of the human life. The project, however, failed to attract the number of visitors anticipated and was consequently shut down. In 2007, however, after undergoing a re-development, the Millennium Dome was reintroduced to the public as 'The O2'. Since then, I must admit that it has evolved into becoming one of the many hotspots of London life. The O2, I think, is the home of the largest entertainment plazas that London has on offer - one of its main attractions being 'The O2 Arena' that has accommodated for the likes of The Rolling Stones, Kylie, Alicia Keys, Bon Jovi, Prince and Take That to name but a few. With an assortment of restaurants [some of the very best in town] alongside bars and clubs and of course the most current and riveting exhibitions - The O2 is definitely worth the visit. Easy tube access, with the nearest station being North Greenwich, The O2 is open until the early hours of the morning on most days to accommodate for your entertainment desires! If you're done exploring the wonders of the internal, then take a stroll under the stars along the Thames for a romantic end to a hectic evening. It can, however, get a little chilly so do bring a big, strong man to keep you warm - or in my case, a cashmere M&S cardigan!

ZSuukHMGs6dGEwVpcvM84A.text: I haven't yet been to this venue for music only for comedy (Russell Brand and Russell Howard) but it is a great venue and is really well laid out to deal with the crowds so you don't get that feeling that you have to leave the gig 5 minutes early in order to make the transport the same way you do at Wembley! The sound really is amazing and they have made it so much more than just a music venue - they also have restaurants and a cinema so even if not for a big event it's definitely worth checking it out.

Uebyfzs1wDEXFLCiFxizNA.text: I've been here a few times now and i must say that other than the expensive prices of the beverages, I have no complaints about the place. There are good transport links, and a large variety of good pubs and restaurants inside. They can put on a good show with the minimum of fuss.

dhFaB-F0qiAGRw1IyvQ8xQ.text: The only reason this venue doesn't get 5 stars is because the queues for lining up for the food restaurants are just ridiculous! Think about it; you got matter - 2,600 capacity, a small intimate concert hall (O2 indigo - capacity 2,400), cinema, concert arena for 20,000 and shops! 21 restaurants with seating for about 100 in each at is best is whack! = 25,000 people possibly at any one time in the arena, so for the amount of people that are in this venue at one time there ain't enough food restaurants! What more could you want in one place, but the food queueing for any event here is just too long! What they need to do, is expand on the food courts, they got enough space to do it! Apart from that, everything else is fantastic, well worth the years of wait for them to do something constructive with the millennium site. I'm glad it has come to be what it is today! Countless good events in a local area! p.s. the car park is officially a ripoff at upto £25 an hour! oh and the capacity 2,500!

3KgwYfU1_avthrh9oEA5wg.text: I have thoroughly enjoyed every visit to the 02 and it's many many attractions. I was lucky enough to attend several of the Prince concerts staged in the concert arena during 2007 and I have to say not one seat gave me a bad view. Every time I had a clear view of the action, plenty of room to move and there was no problems with the sound. Having a central stage (in the round) is a big bonus and something that has been lacking from UK concert venues for too long. The venue is very organised and even with all the cinema goers, clubbers and concert goers - it all seems to run like clock work. The concert venue is very well located in the centre of the 02 and there are plenty of concessions and facilities available. I cannot rate the 02 highly enough ( and that's without gushing about the after show party I attended at Indigo 2 ;0)

17RATcHxCmkTbUvXGgQAWQ.text: The O2 is a cool place to hang out if you enjoy the feeling of living in an Orwellian-esque land. I find the place rather terryfying. We went to see Chris Rock last night in the arena, at a record breaking (for attendance) comedy gig. Half the gig was quite good, the rest was essentially a list of offensive cliches about the differences between men and women, black people and white people, black women and white men and so on ad infinitem. The venue itself felt to me like a sort of sociological experiment. 15,000 people in one room watching one person seems in practicality to be wrong to me. For a band, it might be less weird. We were on the 4th level, at the back. The view was completely unobstructed and we could see almost the entire venue. But again this just reinforced the panoptic 1984 feeling. From the balconies on the 4th floor you can see the tops of all the restaurants on the ground floor (of which there weren't enough to accomodate all the people who were in the O2 last night). Being able to see the tops of the cafes, makes it look like a fake town. Like Sim City 2000. Of course the Millenium Dome (as I will insist on calling it) is an impressive building, mostly in terms of its collosal size. It is quite exciting when you first enter it, but I couldn't shake the feeling of not really being in a 'real' place. Of course, the fact that there are seemingly only chain restaurants in the buidling doesn't help get rid of that corporate sense. I think when the robots have taken over they will enjoy the Millenium Dome.

sUaI2cQyYk8PJxkc_e34nQ.text: The O2 is just ace, definitely a turnaround for what used to be the dome and gloom and all the best artists are now performing here over other venues in town. It's more of an experience, rather than just going out to a gig in a sweaty flea pit. Definitely a must do if you're visiting London and live in London, great to explore a developing area of the city. Loads of nice restaurants to choose from - everything from sushi to Gaucho's, and even an S&M cafe if you like your bangers and mash woohoo! (i'm veggie but they do great veggie sausages). Saw the Spice Girls and the lovely Kylie here recently and travelled to the gigs via ye olde river Thames - loved it! So cool that you can get somewhere in London without needing to get on a smelly tube, added something special to the evening. There's also an S&M cafe on the boat - bangers all round then! ;o)

JvGRuBBWmBVzNrN9NWXdFw.text: I have been to the O2 Arena recently and have been absolutely amzed by the tranformation since Millenium Dome was first built. It has become such a lively place unbelievable packed with activities and great places to hang out. This year alone, I have been there for 3 events. Disney On Ice : Finding Nemo, Nick Evans talk show and Britain Got TalentsEven if you are not going for shows do go and have a look. it's has changed no longer a white elephant it is now a venue!

MhyZ4i_Ix-T5Rx4n3x_jsg.text: Good place to find some good restaurants or bars in the avenue which follows the O2 arena. In the same way you have also some entertainments and a night club.

b47pV9dH0cZk05rHV_SxcQ.text: I was really looking forward to coming to the O2 to see the amazing Kylie Minogue and it definitely didn't disappoint. Although i can understand why some people think that the stage is too small because it is such a huge place i would have expected it to be a bit bigger but never mind as the accoustics were exceptional. There is also a very good selection of bars and restaurents to suit every appetite - i especially love Nando's!!! This is such a great entertainment venue i can't wait to go backalthough the tickets can be more expensive than some smaller venues, its well worth it for the experience!

dL5PiBLVT9it3TOQFYTUTA.text: When I arrived in London in early 2001, the Millennium Dome was a huge joke: the worst failure of an over-hyped let's-kick-off-the-next-1000-years. No one, at the time, thought it would become the most popular ticket-selling venue in the world. I've been there five times, to see Prince, Bruce Springsteen, Roger waters, Duran Duran and Afrika! Afrika! I think that it's just about as amazing as a large venue can be. Access is so simple. The Jubilee Line runs right to it, and your short walk to the front door is entirely under cover. Buses, taxis, and driving are all accommodated for as well, though I can't imagine why you'd bother with the hassle of the last option. The building itself is gorgeous, I think, really interesting. Its only once you're inside that you realise how functional those exterior roof spikes are, because they remove any need for interior sightline-blocking supports. The lobby area is huge and ornate. It's got shops galore. The interior arcade of bars, restaurants, shops, movie theatres, skating rinks seems endless. None of it's cheap, of course, but if you want to beat the crowds, get there early, and have a fancy meal or a few glasses of wine before a show, you're well catered for. The performance area is great. Yes, it's huge, but it's round and very steep at the top, so even when up in the nosebleeds you're much closer than you would expect to be. There are tons of concession stands and toilets on every level. There seem to be plenty of staff on hand at all times, and they're very helpful. I've heard the nightclub-type venue inside the venue - the indigO2 - is quite cool, but I've not been in it yet. They've got lots of fenced-in exterior space, too, which is where they put the Afrika! Afrika! tent. The only painful part of a visit to the O2 is getting to the Tube afterwards. They throttle access into the Underground entrance after shows (to prevent crowds building up at the top of, and on, the descending escalators), which means you can often queue in the crowd for 10 or 15 minutes. I hate the fact that there are acts I can only see at a venue as large as the O2, but if I've got to do it, I can't imagine a better layout for doing so.

7IvLwhQKCTRi0CaAYHQUsw.text: We went here for a Cliff Richard concert (the whole point and climax of me and my mom's trip to London!) and though it is outside the city of London, in Greenwich, it was super easy to get to via the Jubillee line. Best part is, the station is literally in front of the massive entertainment center, so no need to plan for extra travel. The architecture is very futuristic, and it was a nice contrast to all the historical buildings we were touring in London. There are many smaller food vendors in one fantastic looking building outside the main stadium, and once you enter you are met in a rather large quarter of restaurants and shops and clubs. It looks like you can enjoy your time before a big show or event at one of these places. For our show in particular, they had a large souvenir stand before you got into the arena. There were many people manning this station, so we didn't have to wait in line for my mom to get her hands on all her Cliff Richard goodies. The arena itself, for the show, was very comfortable and clean. There were ample amounts of concessions and bathrooms for the most part. The staff was very nice and accommodating (there were many older people at this show! ) My only complaint is that before you enter the stadium for your event, the bathrooms are hard to find and there weren't many of them.

mR-aWFTEY_6g2Q7YH4DP3g.text: From white elephant to funky elephant.I really like what they've done to this big old tent of wonders. So many restaurants to choose from, bars for a tipple, a cinema and, oh, just one of the biggest concert arenas in the country for good measure.Coming here for a show? Then be sure to spring for dinner here too and make a great evening of it. Transport links are good (assuming the pesky J-line is running) and it's actually rather impressive to look at too. Almost justifies the ridiculous amount of money the Government wasted in building the darn thing. Almost.

H1ykBfemnPl0CRVwnKWHZg.text: O2 is conveniently located for us over on the East side and makes for an easy afternoon / evening out, whether you are planning to go to the Arena for a concert, the cinema or a bite to eat.  The cinema is reasonably priced and boasts one of the largest 3D screens (I forget whether that's in the UK or Europe... either way, I was impressed!).  It also means that you can grab a bite to eat either before or after the show, and you're not short on choice - from Chinese (not tried it) through to pasta (Pizza Express is ok, Zizzi's is good) and now more recently TGI Fridays (love it!).  I also went to the British Music Experience recently - it was smaller than I imagined it would be, but still entertaining and informative.  The rooms are organised into periods of time (roughly decades, as I recall) and there's a mixture of videos, memorabilia and interactive games.  My favourite bits were the dance video room (if you ever fancied doing the Twist, this is your chance!) and the musical instrument room (you can try your hand at the guitar, bass guitar, drums, piano or singing!).  It's all very high-tech, with tickets containing a barcode that saves all the information from your visit (e.g. your favourite band info, or that video of you doing the Twist...) and then you can view it on the internet when you get home.  I'd say it's worth the money for a visit. Definitely worth a visit if you're stuck on something to do one afternoon.

5Okc_KxCW4yxdX4MozTp6g.text: This is a review for the Cineworld cinema at the O2. One word: Niceeeeeee!The screen was so big - I really enjoyed the movie at the O2 even though it was a crappy movie. I wonder if they have even bigger screens as we were at Screen 7. The seats aren't those silly flappy ones either and they huge and comfortable. They're velvet red and pretty.I will definitely be coming back to this cinema even though the journey time damn near killed me. Food was at the same old extortionate prices (yet I always buy them!) and service at the counter was slow as usual. I don't know what it is about cinema staff and their lackadaisical efforts! Very cool cinema, indeed.

XQC4dSX0ptxr_6zWnC8Ncw.text: millenium dome. O2. better. connected. big. great reception.enough said. =)

vvuWquVSpvSEK-h6Akc9eQ.text: The o2 Centre is one of London's leading events centres. Everyone from Celine Dion to Kings of Leon have played the stage in the massive stadium situated in Greenwich. The last time I was here for the Kylie Minogue tour, and boy was it great. Thanks to some friends we had a box, fully catered for and with a prime spot to view the show.The staff in the box were great - serving Grey Goose cocktails and even taking icecream orders at interval.  The box itself was plush and lovely, with vases of flowers, couches and great seats on the balcony from which to watch the show.  The centre itself is quite stunning, with the entrance to o2 under big light installations and neon lighting.  A must-see to view any big-name concert!

dBJIt0SJRN_hfJedPN7GhQ.text: I visited recently for the Tutankhamun exhibition. As such I haven't got to see the main arena space. However I did get to see the cinema and part of the 'street' that goes round the outside. It's an amazing building. There's loads of cafes of all types. It did seem a little short on loos (though I guess there are loads of them in the individual parts), and we only spotted one shop that wasn't a café. Still it's a great place to wander around among the artificial trees and 'street life'. There's 'installations' to look at, and a place where you can make your own dance video for free. The open area outside on the way back to the tube station is also worth exploring. It doesn't look much, but look closer. There's a water wall, and the Greenwich Meridian cuts through, so you can get your piccy taken on that. At time of writing there was a display relating to the local area, which I didn't get time to look at, and a huge statue of Anubis for the Egyptian exhibition.

0yJEUEcHp_e778JEXvMkeQ.text: The atmosphere in this place is amazing. I went here with some friends from my college course. We had such a fun time, looking around, exploring and we even found a little Sony booth, they had Karaoke. This place is a great little venture, but there isn't a huge amount of stuff. It's just fun, they have a cinema. I will consider coming back here for sure, a lot.

eN8lxDF_oeBS6p3AddDL6A.text: Despite its size, the O2 has amazing acoustics no matter where you sit. Obviously if you want to 'see' the act avoid the upper level unless you're happy with the screens, but if you're happy to just hear, sit anywhere.

photos.caption: Photo of The O2 - London, United Kingdom

l3QfuZoXjJp3e-26p8sSMA.text: Not enough women's toilets.Just saying.Also, when you inevitably pop out in the middle of a gig for a quick pee due to your resolute stand against waiting in the queue before the gig -- once you locate the nearest restrooms, which are a two-minute sprint down the corridor -- you'll be dismayed to find possibly the most ineffective hand dryers known to man.This being said, you better believe I'm coming back to the O2 in March to see Cesar Millan in motherfucking Dog Whisperer World Tour.

Itu7ZM3nkSMk5QDJEj49eA.text: As the crow flies, I live just over a mile from the 02, and it has become a regular destination - mainly for the Vue cinema (which has several auditoria, including one reputed to be the biggest in London), and maybe to eat in one of the many restaurants built around the periphery of the Arena (Pizza Express, Thai Silk, etc). Be warned, though, there are no cheap places to eat.There are a couple of large bars (including a Slug & Lettuce), coffee shops, an 02 shop (naturally), a news-agent, and - at busy times - a few free-standing stalls selling expensive nick-nacks.When there's a big event in the Arena, it can get very crowded and queues for the restaurants quickly build up, so it pays to arrive early if you want to eat before going to the event. If you are planning a cinema trip, it might also be worth checking what's on in the 02 before you travel - I went once when Cliff Richard was on - couldn't move for grey-haired Cliff fans!Be careful to check if you are driving as the carparks can be extortionately expensive (Vue cinema ticket holders, however, can get their parking for free). It may be better to park locally and get a bus up to North Greenwich (remember your Oystercards).Along from the restaurants are a couple of large open areas that are used to house other more temporary visitor attractions. Over the past three years, there's been a skating rink (2007), a ski slope (2008) and Carter's Steam fun-fair in the winter (almost deserted on Christmas Eve 2009, but also expensive - and some of the operators.... well, let's just say they weren't full of the Christmas Spirit!). A roller disco and an indoor beach have livened up the past two summers.

qPcJgO9sXE8rQi9m0LWYGA.text: 02 has come to save millennium dome! 02 is like a little town under one roof! They should put it on the global map as a city.I would recommend this place for friends, family and you can even go by yourselfWide range of restaurants and cafes to choose from. 02 has a concert venue, a mini concert venue, exhibition hall (I went to Michael Jackson Exhibition and I was so happy it was held at the 02), confectionery shop, a cinema, bar's and nightclubs!Just by the train station, bus station and even Thames clipper.

ccxuZOyEt-fb3SpZCMOL7w.text: Well done Mr. O2 for turning a White (dome-shaped) Elephant into a top arena! I must say, I hate the "village" aspect of the O2 with the silly, overpriced bars and restaurants. But the actual arena is wonderful. One of the better barns for acoustics, the O2 Arena possesses a decent clarity, even when I have sat in areas that normally sound woolly and inarticulate in other large venues. The rake and angle of seats are very conducive to having a decent view of the stage. My preference is having the stage set "in the round" as it was when Prince Nelson was hanging out there. Last night I went to see Norwegian-black-and-white-cartoon-characters, a-ha. It was a surprisingly good gig, especially as you get what you pay for. And I paid nothing. The gig itself labored a little in the middle, due to the fact that 10,000 people and I did not know any of the songs between "The Nun Always Climbs on T.V.s" and "Cryyyyy Wooooooolf (Wooooo-oooooo)". They had me won back again, especially with "The Living Daylights", but that's because I like Timothy Dalton as Bond. He had the best Aston. But was Welsh. And had a dent in his chin. Another treat last night was the corporate hospitality. Having a room to relax in before the gig is always nice, but having waitress service, free bar and full meal makes me begrudge having to resume watching gigs like a serf. The only fly in the ointment is using the Jubilee line after a gig - you are herded like an animal to the station and cram onto a tube if you are lucky to get one. And woe betide you staying a little late and missing the last train. The last time that happened, my then-girlfriend and I were so pissed off with each other that it ended the relationship. Either that, or the Ann Widdecombe impersonator with the large glasses and Red Piano that we had watched perform that night had poisoned our young and impressionable minds. Each explanation is plausible.

Zlf0_-Nunc3IAFqjAkHWRg.text: Ok, this is one MASSIVE stadium. The floor seats (section B for the Bon Jovi Circle tour) were amazing. I saw the rest of the people all the way up or behind the stage, and I felt both sorry for them and slightly queasy at how high up they were. The sound is brilliant, but a bit of a "puddle" is formed in the middle as the waves reverberate off the back and sides. So a good balance, but oh my god it was loud! Odd thing: they don't let you take bottles of water with their caps inside. They keep the caps. Also, you can't bring in water from beyond the security check when you get your ticket verified. Yes, almost like a flight post 9-11. Also, they sell 500ml bottles for £2.50 in there. Monopoly, anyone? Overall I'd say that getting a seat near the front, even if it's on the side, is definitely worth more than a seat all the way at the back but in the centre. Because at least you'd get to see. The venue is absolutely HUGE.

7eU3JQp89mXo2FoNgpsbcg.text: If you want to eat before a concert at the O2 Arena, I have a tip for you. Get there early, and decide where you want to eat right away. We got there early, and were almost immediately attracted by a rather nice Thai restaurant. BUT . 'Let's see what else there is before we go firm on it!' That was a mistake, for there are an awful lot of food outlets within the Arena. By the time we'd checked them all, read their menus and returned to the Thai restaurant, we were told there'd be a 30 minute wait before we could even be seated. And, the concert started in 45 minutes. So, the search had to be confined to places where we could be seated and served almost straight away. The one we chose was the 'Armadillo', which wouldn't, normally, have been my first choice. They try desperately to 'be American', but don't quite make it. There's American beer on offer, but there's also Beck's beer  which is better and cheaper. I found the music a little too loud for my tastes, and the restaurant was a little crowded. But, nevertheless, the service was slick and efficient, and we couldn't complain about the food; fish and chips and a chili burger. It's just that the ambience doesn't quite do it for me.

YJMvLPdM_aNjZ5ribxXsKw.text: Ogromna hala sportowo/eventowo/koncertowa, fajnie zaprojektowana z całym mnóstwem barów i knajpek. Miałam okazję oglądać tam mecze koszykówki, koncerty i wystawy. Myślę, że jeśli masz okazję być na płycie, w miarę blisko sceny to jest OK, ale jeśli trafią ci się miejsca w jednym z ostatnich rzędów, to lepiej nie iśc wcale. Odległość jest tak wielka, że równie dobrze mogliby postawić na scenie kilku kolesi, puścić Kings of Leon z playbacku i też bym uwierzyła, ze to oni. Oczywiście są telebimy, ale to nie to samo. Wolę mniejsze, bardziej kameralne sale koncertowe. Jak dla mnie, to miejsce nie ma atmosfery.

rx04r2M54o2hFg40OOsMRw.text: Fantastic music venue.  And lots of places to eat and drink.  Fun things to do also.  Cinema and bowling.  Would recommend it to everyone

FkrYYYwxiOQmxz92OB2v5g.text: I saw Bon Jovi here a little while ago (why must you mock me for this? Hmmmm?), and we got tickets in a swanky corporate booth. Hurrah! Yes, hurrah indeed. But this mean that there wasn't really much singing along. The acoustics were great, but if you're away form the action, and can't sing along unless feeling like you're at karaoke, you'll feel pretty odd. Especially when Bon jovi is so singalongable to. Shush, that's a word. The stage is amazing (unless you've got the seats behind the stage - really, what's the point?) and the sound is good. The whole place is shiny, well organised and I had a fab time. Even though I wish I'd been right in the old man rock action. Still, it's only a 20 minute walk back home, and I can't say that about Wembley.

Ntp0O6XM2m9kUdxEv99LRw.text: The Titanic Artefacts Exhibition is on at present. I travelled up from Reading to Waterloo then tubed to North Greenwich. It was only a short walk to the O2. Having been to the original exhibition in the Wembley arena just before Wembley Stadium was demolished I was pleased to see all the artefacts again. Added was the system of rooms and cabins as they were on the Titanic. If you are interested in things Titanic it is worth the visit. I spent a lot of time looking round, I think I will have to visit again to see I may have missed.

z_KsWLUkLABFiQSV5Gvmmg.text: Owwwwwwwww!!!That's the sound of my soul being sucked out of me! This venue reeks of capitalist venture, the kind of place that looks good when it's a model on someones table but in real life is little more that an excessively large plastic nipple. The food court reads like a who's who of the big chain (so called) restaurants, good god there's people queuing ACTUALLY queuing for pizza express! It has fake trees, a fake street, fake smiles, fake air... If this place were an actor it'd be Fake Gyllenhaal. If this place were an Eagles song it's be Fake it to the limit. The seats at the top are a little steep and can bring on vertigo which I don't mind so much, the view was good and, luckily for this reviewer, Stevie Wonder's love can be felt from quarter of a mile away! Oh yeah he was sooo worth it, not sure I'll be getting tickets to Coldplay supported by Jay-Z (wtf!?) though, or the 15th round of strictly high school factor on ice!If this place were a movie it's be Planet of the fakes.

Uhg5uzjPWNrV87JKMfMZRg.text: I have been to the O2 four times now, three times to see bands and another for the cinema and I think it's fantastic. Good points are: there is a great selection of restaurants and bars (although on nights when live acts are playing, be prepared to queue). The actual music venue is enormous with the 'nose bleed' seats being very high up so avoid if you are fearful of heights. In the actual concert venue there are good bars and food vendors. The amenities are excellent, clean toilets, friendly staff. The cinema was excellent also, when big films are showing there are multiple screens showing the film and at frequent intervals so as not to disappoint.Downsides are: queuing for restaurants on nights when live acts are playing (sometimes up to 40mins) so get there early. With the venue being so big if you do get a seat near the back you may not enjoy the atmosphere quite as much. It is definitely worth a visit if only to see how they have made good use of the millennium dome.

mRlN03feMLhrlgtqOCfd4g.text: The O2, formerly known as the Millenium Dome is a cool place to hang out over the weekend with your partner or a group of friends. The O2 hosts a number of retsuaraunts, including chains such as Nando's, Zizi's and Gaucho and others such as Las Iguanas, which is a Latin American restaurant and cocktail bar, there are also many American Grill places there. The revamped venue also has a number of bars and clubs, a cinema with a large number of screens and particularly expensive tickets and of course, what it is known for, it's concert venue, which is now taking a substantial amount of business from Wembley Arena. The O2 has been a host to many of music's biggest players, Alicia Keys, Kanye West, 50 Cent, Spice Girls and the phenomenal Prince. I have heard many frequent concert goers complain about the prices of tickets at the O2 in comparison to Wembley as now they are forced to go to the O2 and pay the O2's ticket prices to see their favourite artists. Nevertheless, I like the O2, it's located a mere fifteen minute drive from where I live and offers a variety of things to do all in one stone throw away from the next. There are always exhibitions and interactive things to do, it reminds me very much of City Walk in Orlando Fl. Transport is also great here, the Jubilee line runs right to North Greenwich station, which is where the O2 is located, security is particularly strict here, searches are carried out and metal detectors are located at the entrance.The only annoying thing about the O2 is that many bars close early due to being quiet for business, which means you can never gage what time your night may end. I found that on a Friday night most bars by eleven o clock were getting ready to close, we ended up heading to Urban Inc, a club in the O2, which was the only place open and staying open until three.If you haven't checked this place out yet then I would definitely recommend you do!

YEUlqWfZ4ksKEBnhV99Vnw.text: It is one of the biggest entertainment destination hosting concerts for major musicians life Prince, Bon Jovi and Spice Girls. The dome like structure also has other attractions like cinemas, restaurants, bars and shops. Great place to have a day out!

dSOrm_-H0lbt87n49D7PAA.text: I went here just after it opened last year and was really disappointed by the whole 'temporary' feel to the place. Having said that they did hold the brilliant Tutankhamun exhibition which was breathtaking

vIbgH0G-9OSSMayjibtwvg.text: Went to the O2 Arena in July 2008 to see Kylie Minogue perform a concert and I was awestruck as It was really a huge place,My brother had met Dad and I as Dad and I had come by train from Devon to London and I enjoyed being at the 02,I was shown to my seat by a Staff member and she was very nice indeed to me and made me feel welcome and showed me where to go and introduced me to more staff if I needed something,I really rate the 02 Arena 10/10.

3phKXycjKIi5r3-E8Z5tbA.text: Great venue, just what London needs. I have been to rock concerts & comedy gigs at the o2 so far & I love the atmosphere every time I visit. It never disappoints. My only reservation is some of the seats at the very top of the arena are extremely high and are not recommended for people who have a fear of heights. The staff are always friendly & helpful and transport links to and from the o2 in every direction are always very good (DLR, Thames Clipper, Jubilee Line, Bus or even car)

bR5E9xnvvWJaNAmy0aOQYQ.text: The o2 is an excellent place to go. It houses dozens of restaurants and bars. There is a multi screen cinema and a large concert arena where top star attractions perform. It is so nice to see the old Millenium Dome put to good use at last. I seem to remember on my last visit that there was a beach area complete with sand and deck chairs, people were sitting enjoying a drink and listening to a DJ. There can be a problem with public transport regarding the Jubilee line tube at weekends as the trains are often stopped due to engineering works.

Bc8GKSP7ep8u5pDj26ppEA.text: The O2 arena is a fantastic venue to go see any music act. However there are also other places to visit even if there are no performers. There is a selection of restaurants within the O2 that are lined along an artificial street. It feels almost like you are outdoors! It is also very conveniently located next to North Greenwich station, which allows immediate access as soon as you leave the station. There is also a cinema inside to watch all the latest films! However, once you go outside there is very little going on, it is a bit of a baron wasteland. So if you do plan on exploring around the O2 I would advise you hop on a bus and go into Greenwich town centre.

Zd8hPwwXC944C7DaKF53Tg.text: Not the easiest place to get to but what an impressive venue for gigs and to just have a night out eating or drinking.Using the river taxi is a fun way to arrive and the layout and facilities are great. Easy to find your way around and plenty to choose from when eating or drinking.The concert hall itself is well designed offering great sound and a perfect view from every seat.

Q6BfUM0HDPgjuoa1ztdZNg.text: if you are going to see a concert make sure your close to to stage....if you are at the back you are wasting your money as the sound is crap

Il1oRzvck1EiTXe3YY5FgA.text: This place is incredible! I went to the Coldplay concert there last month and we couldn't believe how enormous it was! We were sat quite far back at the top but still had a fantastic view. I love what they've done with the place. Apparently it's one of the most popular music venues and one of the most lucrative. There are a hundred places to eat and drink before a concert - in fact I would go back all that way even if I wasn't going to a concert! It's fab!

Y-2r31G5LBSVloH12QB4Sg.text: Love the venue - great acoustics for music and sport. lots of places to eat and drink inside and around the venue. Try The Gaucho for a good steak or a drink or two at the fantastic bar there.

emUC0zqUvHxQqMML4PYH0A.text: have been a couple of times now, unless you live nearby, you must leave with plenty of time to spare. although fairly easy access to the O2 , there always seems to be hold up with the trains or bus lines. the actual concert venue there are good bars and food vendors , but pricey. been in various seating arrangements now. ,if your close to the actual gig lovely but if you are slightly up or near the back from the main stage, you have got to have a good sense of heights and the acoustics are not much. unfortunately the last time we went ( late notice) at the back of the stadumthe atmosphere isnt quite as good.

TD02B5i_RY2Dw_KLPcIyaA.text: This is an absolutely amazing music venue! I tend to prefer more intimate venues when I go to see gigs but some artists will only do the big arenas and this is definitely the best one I've ever been to! I've been 3 times to see Justin Timberlake (just after it opened) and the Spice Girls! It's absolutely huge with a floor, level one tier and a very high up tier (level four). I wouldn't recommend the fourth tier if you're scared of heights. I've only been on the fourth tier once when I received free tickets from a friend and I was scared to stand up cos we were such a long way up! And obviously the artist is like a dot in the distance haha. The floor has absolutely amazing views though as you're right in the middle of the action and the first tier is good too you're a bit away but you still get a very decent view! They also have a good range of places to eat and drink, as well as a cinema and club. The little indigo2 club does more intimate gigs which is great - I saw Timbaland there after the Justin Timberlake gig I attended and it was very good. Very intimate and after he'd left everyone partied on - it sort of turned into a club. Only downsides are the expensiveness of the food etc (but it's the same anywhere really!) and that it's over commercialised.

rnk4YIIWXIWZto3I8_zcHw.text: Great selection of restaurants but the atmosphere is very cold. The Tut exhibition was limited and was like trying to view the Mona Lisa in the summer. Every piece on exhibit was placed in tiny viewing rooms compared to the sheer amount of people and everyone is squashed up against one another. The center itself was freeing and for a city that spends most of its time living in the colder seasons it makes you want to run and find a blanket and a fire to warm up next to!

h-2O8ljlzVLyjavLl2_DIw.text: An excellent venue for just about anything, Clubs, Concerts, Food, Shooping and in a great location, also holds various exhibitions. A great place to go for a day out with the family or on a night out with the girls, can be a little expensive but only if you choose it to be. In the central of london with a main station so easy to get to, and into other parts of London.

XGvw3yKxsKOtOHjcqjRT6w.text: Been to the O2 twice now to see the Ultimate fighting championship. First time i went was a terrible experience. Long story short (because there was a hell of alot wrong) - The staff were rude and abrupt, they confiscated my camera on the premise that no unauthorised photography was allowed they were then really rude when we left and got our camera back. Anyway after 7 months of trying to get someone to listen to my complaint and give me a straight answer (7 months i kid you not) i was contacted by the head of the O2 who apologised profusely and offered me complementary tickets to an event of my choosing and free parking for the event too! She took on board all of my issues and alleviated my grievance. When i returned to see the UFC again on my free tickets there was a noticeable change in the way the staff were acting (for the better) and the whole place seemed much much better. The arena itself is a pretty impressive building and unlike anything else you will visit. Only gripe is the acoustics arnt really up to much So the first experience was a 1 star venue but the second was a 4 star venue so i've give then a 3 star overall.

n_BBdWrDT7UkW0SlYpgsAA.text: Everybody knows about the O2 as a venue, but it is not until one actually visits it that you can fully apprecite that its a fabolous place to hang out!it has every restuarant and bar you could possibly wanteverything from nandos to starbucks, in fact i think it even has a club, all set inside the o2 which always has events taking place.and only 20 minutes on the tube from central london.

18chNojttZw3VJIcW5-w0Q.text: Ok, yeah.  Wow.  This place is cooler than ice and a huge surprise in comparison to its very urban ugly surroundings.  On an approach to the location, it does look like a white carcass of something dead, I'll agree with that.  But we were particularly impressed with the ease with which we found a place to park.  When approaching the entrance, you find yourself under subtle covered walkways that run past various food stops and cigarette vendors.  When we walked inside, we were asked to go through security, apparently, but the accent of the security people was difficult to understand and so in my confusion I wandered right by.  Nobody stopped me at all or questioned my entrance, which was perhaps a bit worrisome.  It makes one think that perhaps the security is all a show to make people feel better because it took nothing for me to just cruise on by.  Inside the dome are a variety of eateries including Pizza Express, Zizzi, a nightclub, theatre, etc.  On this occasion we were visiting the indigo2, which I'm told is a smaller more intimate venue for music and other smaller events.  The place was cool, I'll give it that.   Indigo lighting, very modern silver decor, a long sprawling busy bar, hardwood floors, and seating that didn't appear, at first glance anyhow, to be clausterphobic at all.  I'll admit some discontent at having to pay £3 for a small bottle of Buxton water...especially since they were making people leave their water at the door.  The mark-up was ridiculous, but okay, whatever, they're making their money I get it.  The sound system was fantastic, and the event itself was great.  Keep in mind, though, that while the seats look airy, they aren't at all in practice.  Even tiny people were shoulder to shoulder with one another, and as two fatties we found that we were incredibly uncomfortable and wishing we'd bought another seat to give more room to the poor folks on either side of us.  Be sure to plan for this if you're tall or wide or both.  Also, because there was no way to get out of your seat once you got into it, everyone's beer cups ended up spilled on the floor.  Since there was nowhere else to put one's purse, my handbag was covered in gross beer by the end of the night.  This is pretty standard for a concert, I suppose, but I found it irritating because the venue was *so* nice you'd think they'd be beyond that by now.   The other major complaint was that upon leaving the location, trying to pay for parking was absolutely ridiculous.  If you park in Car Park 2, plan to queue up at the one and only parking machine for at least an hour...and forget it if it's raining because there's no cover what-so-ever.  Other than that, though, I was impressed by this location and can't wait to find a reason to go back for something else!

zfoIb7NLN04n7RMJtn6Ygg.text: Have been to the O2 to see Afrika Afrika and went to the S&M for a quick bite before we went in and was very disappointed with the food. Recently went back to see the Blue Man Group at the arena and that was fab. However, once again it was the food outlets that let the place down. We tried to get a hotdog, 2 bottles of water and some popcornthey were out of hotdogs and popcorn so all we could have was the water (which was very expensive) and they had to give it to us with the lids off which was not very good with 2 young girls. After the show the girls were very hungry but of course there were queues at all the eateries so we got in the car and went to a place nearby. The very overpriced parking also let the place down. It could do with a couple of fast food restaurants or failing that just some hotdog/burger/popcorn stands on event days to feed the hordes.

CPlc-wIiudEhJwgKCxuAow.text: Of course I had a fabulous time here anyway because I was at the NKOTBSB concert, but this venue is really spectacular!  Getting there is easy... Jubilee Line to North Greenwich and follow the crowds.  If you are making a night of your concert/show, there are loads of restaurants and bars, both outside of the complex and inside.  Obviously most of them are chain restaurants, but still reasonable prices.  Some of the restaurants were busier than others... loads of queues spilling out into the walkway, but with a concert and the film festival, it wasn't as bad as I thought it would be.Work BFF and I chose the Thai restaurant that was decent.  No wait, quick service, however, you did have to order off of one of their set menus.  As we walked to the entrance to the arena, there was even a bar with a set up conveniently on the walkway for those wanting a drink as they walked around.  Once you go in, there are various food/drink/souvenir vendors on each level.  Everything from fish and chips to popcorn and candy.The arena is massive, but we had pretty good seats... not to mention the guys were in the crowd... not just the seats on the floor, but up in the stands!  On the display around the arena, it told everyone when the last tube would be departing for Central London!  Getting out of the O2 took some doing and the obstacles on the walkway:  the chairs and things from the restaurants really slowed the crowd down, but the crowd still moved at a good pace.  Going into the tube station was a bit chaotic, but not once were we stood absolutely still... the crowd was still moving forward.  Even on the platform and getting on the tube, it wasn't overly crowded.  Really impressed with that many people!

4Vnalrqwd58ZWXrTf3Cvig.text: This review is for IndigO2, the smaller venue adjacent to The O2. My favorite band, Wolfmother, performed an epic show at IndigO2 on 6 July 2012. Seeing as it was only 5 or so Pounds more than the standard ticket, we went for the Kings Row VIP seating and loved it. Kings Row includes a whole lounge area with a private bar and TV screens, comfortable lounge-style seating, and a separate VIP entrance. Worth every penny. I wish we had arrived a little earlier to enjoy the lounge more, but we never had to wait in line to order a drink and the prices were very reasonable for a concert venue in London (rum and coke and a double gin and tonic for approximately 12 Pounds). The acoustics are excellent, no echo and a very balanced sound. The opening act, Turbowolf, was terrible but that's certainly not the fault of IndigO2. The only thing that could be improved was the lighting. The lighting effects seemed off-the-cuff and not well coordinated with the music, as if programmed by someone with absolutely no familiarity with Wolfmother's songs. So, down a star for that. The bouncers were even pretty cool, very flexible and enjoying themselves while doing their job effectively. We even caught them rocking to the music on occasion. Overall, a very relaxed venue.In the end, the show as spectacular, the venue was great, and King's Row ended up being worth it. If you're looking for the mosh-pit experience, though, you will obviously want the standing area downstairs.

5EKvF4pJg6DaqPoF93kzzg.text: So I am one of those Nine Inch Nails fans that makes a vacation out of a few NIN tour dates. When they announced their UK/EU dates for the spring, I knew I had to come to London to see them. Unfortunately, with the time difference and a bit of indecision on my part, we got tix up in nosebleed. I figured it would be okay since NIN shows have great visuals and in the end I wasn't disappointed.Even though the venue is ginormous, the sound was great and so were the sight lines. I took a few videos and the sound quality was way better than I thought it would be which definitely speaks for the acoustics. The seats were comfortable (not like I sat in them for most of the show), but I appreciated being able to sit for a bit after some standard show dancing/fist pumping, etc.Pro-tips: do I even have to say that the Tube was the best way to get in and out of the show? There are a bunch of bars/restaurants/etc around the arena for pre or post show shenanigans if you're feeling uninspired to make real plans before or after.

5BBnnVAe__6BNyp_rQXP1w.text: I just love this place!!My all time fav place.I go there every weekend to watch movie at cine world.Thumbs up!!

40hhPood1WmDZff12Ad9RQ.text: The O2 knocks Wembley into a cocked hat. The perfect venue for any performance. War of the Worlds was fantastic and, need I say it, The Moody Blues were, as always, superb.Plenty of restaurants and bars around the venue. Plenty of car parking space, although expensive.

aK0u91UiqxuSpkpycsCelg.text: i just wanted to say, They totally let me loose in the nissan innovation station area of the o2. As in, Got to drive around the their mini electric car, on real roads.Be very afraid.

wwMk9kD_ecTcLiPl8sfWZg.text: Great for the cinema (cineworld inside) but hideous to get out of when there is an event because there is only one tube option. If you are getting the bus then go in the left queue for taxis and go around the outside to save yourself a queue.

Jn1NZ6yDlDAp9GfVy4yZZg.text: I like the 02! I like seeing gigs here because the journey home is super quick and easy. I do find it strange that if you have standing tickets you have to go to a totally different entrance to seating tickets, but it's never put me off. It's just a bit of a walk half way around the dome to get to your entrance! I also like meeting my boyfriend here in the evening for a meal because again, it is really easy to get to via transport. There are plenty of places to eat - some good, some not so. Parking is expensive though, so I always bus it here. Theres also a cinema and coffee places such as Starbucks and regular exhibitions.

r3bKQpsoH4uYgosW0g-2sw.text: In an ideal world, I've discovered all my favorite acts well before they've become popular, and am therefore able to see them in tiny, intimate venues.  Sadly, this isn't always the case, and enter the O2 which seems to be the preferred large venue for highly popular acts coming to London.  And as large arenas go, the O2 is pretty tops!I remember visiting London in 2000 when I believe it had just been finished as the Millennium Dome, and my cousins saying to me "that massive thing over there is the Millennium Dome" or something along those lines.  Fast forward to 2012, when I visited the first time to see Muse.  And again more recently to see Keane.  The O2 is an amazing entertainment complex, filled with a zillion food/drink options (TGI Fridays, Nandos, Gaucho, etc., etc.) and a Cineworld.  Bear in mind that when walking into the O2 complex, you're not actually "inside" so on cold nights, wandering around can be a bit frigid.  If you intend to eat at the O2 on a concert night, I believe you can book ahead at some of the places.As a concert venue, the sound is pretty decent as far as large arena concerts go.  If you're seated in the upper levels, it can be quite steep and precarious to get to your seats, but if you're lucky enough to be in the lower bowl, well, then... you're quite lucky!  My main gripe about the O2 would have to be that they have a very limited exit strategy.  That being, ONE exit for all.  So when a sold out concert is released, you may be stuck in a crowd for quite some time trying to make your way to said exit.  Especially if your seats are all the way in the H or I seating area (which was the case for both my visits).  Not exactly convenient or safety friendly in my mind!I'm sure I'll be making my way to the O2 time and time and time again during my London tenure.  And I'm quite okay with that!

7Fe9RK06oz5HW-uE9OzyGQ.text: I JUST WATCHED LOUIS CK PERFORM HERE!AHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHIt was a sold out show. He had mentioned there being 12,000 people, though wikipedia lists it as having a 20,000 person capacity.I've also seen Walking with Dinosaurs here.Arena is big, etc etc. What I think is important to know is that it does get hot inside. With so many people, it warms up fairly quickly. Both times I was there it felt quite warm. So, just be prepared for that.

0ai5_GBH8qMJzwTo6T0T3w.text: Saw Dolly Parton here - AWESOME. Had no clue the extent of this venue, very American in its style and setup. Plenty of restaurants to choose from though definitely book before you go if you want to go to one of the nicer restaurants. We didn't and ended up at a quick and cheap sushi joint as everywhere else had long lines. Highly recommend for dinner and a concert.

cTfOTSLeoqZvo3IKZYTwZg.text: Saw the Stones here last night.  Great venue.  Bravo to O2 for bringing this thing back from the dead!

4dJqAqFbqcm2hoOHPzFmgw.text: Every year for our birthdays, a friend of mine and myself decide to treat each other with a birthday based activity - presents get so mundane right!So we popped to the O2 to climb its 52 foot high dome and see what we could see. We could see London.We went at sunset, so romantic! Not thinking about that, we were of course in a group full of couples, bleurgh. So we made fun of everyone to their disgust. Oh well! We had a brief safety announcement and then up we popped. You basically get attached to the stairs that lead you up to the viewing platform and clamber up. It's a weird feeling, the stairs aren't exactly solid so you do tend to bounce around a bit. The climb starts quite steeply as well so feel yourself srambling to get up but it levels out and you get a good 20 minutes at the top to look around and take in the sights - Canary Wharf on one side and random other bits of London on the other. I had fun watching the planes come in to City airport to land and waving at the people in the Air Emirates cable cars that go from the O2 over to the Excel centre. Then you scramble down and try incredibly hard not to fall, more difficult going down because the steep part is even steeper. Dear God! Definitely a good work out for the legs.All in all, not an unpleasant experience, but frankly a bit boring. Better than a generic card and box of chocolates though!

fsyMaL1f3Fqhe7uCpXebvA.text: My friends and I decided to do Up at the 02 for my birthday and we chose the sunset climb.  I have to say I was very excited and petrified, I hate heights absolutely hate them, we got there early so we stood outside and watched another group go up which had some older children so I figured if they could do it so could I.You check in, fill in a safety form then you are shown a corny but good safety video after that you are kitted out in your safety harness, boots and jumpsuit. You are given another quick safety/ rules chat at the bottom of a set stairs then your harness is double checked by guide before you go up to platform where they take your picture and then you begin.My friends volunteered for us to go first so I wouldn't back out lol it was odd at first because walkway was like walking on a trampoline, it was a hard go on the way up quite steep but wow oh wow is it worth it when you get to top platform what a view!!!! You have about 15 mins to wander around top platform which is plenty of time then you begin your decent. I quite enjoyed the decent bit but a lot people didn't guess it's personal preference. The whole climb took about an hour but I definitely think it was worth money and time I want to do it again :-) the guides are very conscious of safety and made the experience a great time. Definitely recommend going

m5m-VmnRF7QxsLZ-Tv6_RA.text: This place is pretty special. First of all the O2 is the best reincarnation we've yet seen for the beforehand ill-fated Millennium Dome. The O2 is fast becoming London's première music venue. The line ups for gig's can simply be described as the best you will ever see. It is the home for super club Matter, and some of the best exhibitions in the world have graced this architectural wonder. There is a cinema and a multitude of mid-range restaurants and eateries to keep you topped up before a gig.Due to the sheer size, it is almost impossible for the place to hold a buzzy atmosphere. Yet once you enter one of the many attractions, there is certainly fun to be found.

photos.caption: Photo of The O2 - London, United Kingdom

xJzHftiVbieTgJTgcRHK7A.text: OK  a once in a lifetime experience..and I would only do it once!!! The venue is huge and unless youv'e got a seat near the stage, you could feel left out of the ocassion. I can't say tha we had a bad experience but it just wasn't for us at those prices. We often stay in North Greenwich and jump on the tube into Town. Would recommend O2 Qypers to stay at the Holiday Express at the beginning of Millenium Way and walk up to the arena.

FAfOHJF1vySr152OrEdJcw.text: We came here to see Star Wars in Concert at the O2 Arena on Saturday - it was fantastic! I knew that there were loads of disruptions on the tube over the weekend so we caught the 188 bus at Waterloo which took us (the very long way round) here - it took about an hour. Had to get a replacement bus service to some station somewhere on the way back so that took a lot longer - bit confusing if you're not used to transport in London but we made it : ) Anyway, great venue - massive, spacious, staffed by helpful enough people. Plenty of toilets, although there were still long queues. What really got me mad were the drinks prices though. I know you expect to pay more somewhere like this, but £4.50 for a tiny bottle of cider? So I had to get 2 each time, in a pint glass, so between 2 of us we spent over £30 on drinks. For a 2 hour show. Which I think is ridiculous.

hXjgSiLdkDjoxD9QUIt0fQ.text: The o2 pretty much has everything the place is huge you could play hide and seek here and never be found, it has a great choice in place to eat drink and buy stuff .I've been twice my first time was to do a boat trip along the Thames and I didn't get to stay and do much here so I came back again for a beer with pals, what a great night it's prices are pretty much what you pay in the city so it's not cheap but well worth a visit.Its also  pretty easy to get to but it does get busy when major events are on so give your self plenty of time to get there,  Next time I come i must try the food and not just get drunk.

HByyjniJevBPE9UqDQroxg.text: Here for the London prepares series. Venue for spectating is superb, but the food prices are not just high, they are 300% mark up and service is poor. Don't buy stuff, enjoy the venue

photos.caption: Photo of The O2 - London, United Kingdom

qolE41GAhn2kC5l4XsItTg.text: Ahhh The O2, what a turn out. It was like watching your child turn from a spotty teenager into a dully fledged adult. The Millennium Dome... was, erm...  Special. After a year we all sat there thinking, "what the frig are they going to turn this monstrosity into?" and finally there was a result.I've been here a few times, for gigs, exhibitions, to go clubbing. It's like the shopping mall of life. Now you might all wonder why I am giving this dome of commercialism a full five stars, well here it is: All Under One Roof. Yup, it's that simple, everything is here in one place, the cinema, the BME, a selection of satisfactory food chains, a huge arena. Not only that but it's in the middle of nowhere but they have made transport as easy as possible. They even have fountains outside.This place is still terrifying. It's huge and it's easy to get lost in but the facilitates are unbeatable. If there is something you want to see here, go, you will not be disappointed.

caqHwLkU5-MxvHIN0malVw.text: The best large size concert venue in London. There are restaurants and a cinema in the same complex as well as a smaller O2 venue on site.

4rMsVvDln-LS8WIW1jt-1g.text: I know, I know, I know...a review of a venue is probably gonna be affected by how great the actual event attended was.  Let's just count that as my little disclaimer.5 stars!I went to the 02 last weekend for the Country2Country festival.  I am not a big country music listener, but was buoyed by the promise of beers poured into pint glasses the shape of cowboy boots (these never materialized, but the dream was there).The venue was great.  The security was totally on-point (we were trying to rush the stage / line dance simultaneously) without being overly pushy or officious.  The beer queues were short.  The bathrooms (other than one post-concert rush) were clean and quick for in/outs.  Sound good.  Big screens good.  Live in central-ish London?  Well double-win because the Tube access is simple and easy-peasy.I think I'm at an age where I generally am snobby about big arena things* "oh, the O2?  Naaaaah" used to be my standard line.  But no longer!  Country music or anything else I'm down for more O2-ing.*unless it's Beyonce.  YONCE, ALWAYS.Yelp note: NEXT UP - USHER AT THE 02 WHADDUP!!!

xtujBHyUmOMh6L2YzWdDzg.text: We stayed not far from The O2 and on our way home at night, we wanted to go for a movie. The nearest Cineworld was at this place. It was my first time at The O2 as I never get to come around here when in London. I thought it was just the arena. I was surprised to find out it's a shopping centre. Not just one or two shops but lots of shops and restaurants. We got the last screening at the cinema as the one before was booked out. Had about an hour to spare. Decided to go for a meal. Looking around for places to eat and most were closing down. Las Iguanas was still opened for another hour or less. Ate there.Ofcourse the famous O2 arena is in there and it's one of the big entertainment venue in London. Lots of big concerts and other shows take place here. It is one of the biggest arenas. I would love to go see a show here next time I go.
